content: The Commercial Revitalization Tax Act of 1995 introduces a new Commercial Revitalization Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing tax incentives for commercial revitalization projects. The Commercial Revitalization Tax Act of 1995 introduces a new Commercial Revitalization Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows for a percentage of qualified revitalization expenditures on qualified revitalization buildings over a 10-year credit period. The applicable percentage can be either 20 percent or 5 percent per year, once elected by the taxpayer. The Commercial Revitalization Tax Act of 1995 introduces a new Commercial Revitalization Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows for a percentage of qualified revitalization expenditures on qualified revitalization buildings over a 10-year credit period. The term 'qualified revitalization building' refers to a building located in an eligible commercial revitalization area with a commercial revitalization credit allocated to it and allowable depreciation. The credit allows for a percentage of qualified revitalization expenditures on qualified revitalization buildings over a 10-year credit period. The term 'qualified rehabilitation expenditure' includes amounts chargeable to capital account for nonresidential real property with allowable depreciation. The aggregate amount of qualified revitalization expenditures for any qualified revitalization building in a taxable year shall not exceed $10,000,000. The term 'qualified revitalization expenditure' excludes certain expenditures, such as those not using straight-line depreciation or related to land acquisitions. The term 'eligible commercial revitalization area' refers to designated zones like empowerment zones or enterprise communities. It excludes certain expenditures related to building acquisition costs exceeding 30 percent of qualified revitalization expenditures. Additionally, any expenditure eligible for other tax credits can only be considered for this section if the taxpayer elects to do so. Qualified revitalization expenditures for a qualified revitalization building are taken into account when the building is placed in service. There is a limitation on the aggregate credits allowable with respect to buildings located in a state. The commercial revitalization credit amount for buildings is limited to the amount allocated by the commercial revitalization credit agency. The agency can allocate a portion of the State commercial revitalization credit ceiling for any calendar year. The State commercial revitalization credit ceiling is determined based on the population of low-income census tracts and nonmetropolitan areas within the State compared to all States. The national ceiling amounts are $100,000,000 for 1996, $200,000,000 for 1997, and $400,000,000 for calendar years after 1997. Special rules similar to section 42(h)(3) apply, and low-income areas are considered for eligibility. For this subsection, low-income areas are defined as tracts or areas where at least 50% of residents earn no more than 60% of the median household income. A commercial revitalization credit agency is any state-authorized agency for this purpose, and the term "State" includes US possessions. Commercial Revitalization Credit Agencies must follow specific allocation plans approved by the governmental unit and notify local authorities of projects. The term "qualified allocation plan" outlines selection criteria for commercial revitalization projects, emphasizing contributions to strategic plans, job creation, and community involvement. The section outlines requirements for commercial revitalization projects, including resident and nonprofit involvement, monitoring procedures, and a termination clause for buildings placed in service after December 31, 2000. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to restrict carryback of commercial revitalization credits before enactment.
